lesson.name: Lesson 9.3 Teacher Guide: Completing the Square, Part 2

page.title: 9.3.0: Lesson Overview
page.contents:
Lesson Narrative

In this lesson, students learn that completing the square can be used to solve any quadratic equation, including equations that involve rational numbers that are not integers. Students notice that the process of completing the square is the same when the equations involve messier numbers as when they have simple integers, but the calculations may be more time consuming and prone to error. An error-analysis activity highlights some common errors related to completing the square.

Although any equation can be solved by completing the square, equations that are really difficult to solve by this method are not included here. Students will solve such equations when they have access to the quadratic formula. What is important in this lesson is to recognize that putting a quadratic equation in the form of \((x+p)^2=q\) allows them to solve it, but there are cases in which doing so may not always be the most efficient strategy.

Completing the square for quadratic expressions that are more elaborate encourages students to look for and make use of the same structure that helped them when they were working with less complicated expressions.

Learning Goals (Teacher Facing)

Students will be able to:

  • Express any quadratic equation in the form \((x+p)^2=q\) and solve the equation by finding square roots.
  • Generalize (orally) a process for completing the square to express any quadratic equation in the form \((x+p)^2=q\).
  • Solve quadratic equations in which the squared term has a coefficient of 1 by completing the square.

Learning Targets (Student Facing) 

  • Solve by completing the square when given a quadratic equation in which the coefficient of the squared term is 1.

Texas Essential Knowledge and Skills (TEKS) 


TEKS

Explanation of Coverage

A8(A) solve quadratic equations having real solutions by factoring, taking square roots, completing the square, and applying the quadratic formula.

Partial coverage: Lesson provides content that covers part of this TEKS. The parts that are covered have been underlined.

Lesson Activities

Here are the instructional activities for the lesson:

  • 9.3.1: Solving Equations with Fractions
  • 9.3.2: Using Completing the Square to Solve Equations
    • 9.3.2: Self Check 
    • 9.3.2: Additional Resources
  • 9.3.3: Solve by Completing the Square
    • 9.3.3: Self Check 
    • 9.3.3: Additional Resources
  • 9.3.4: Completing the Square with Fractions

Students will also complete a series of problems in the 9.3.5: Practice.

Required Materials

  • Scientific calculators

Required Preparation

  • None

Lesson Vocabulary

During this lesson, it is important to:

  • Familiarize students with the vocabulary words they will see throughout the lesson.
  • Encourage students to look for these words and notice their use and meanings.
  • Encourage students to use key vocabulary words in "math talk" and their written and oral explanations.
  • Utilize a word wall. Sample cards are located here: Mathematics Vocabulary Word Wall Cards.

Vocabulary words that are emphasized in this lesson:

Previous Vocabulary

New Vocabulary
  • completing the square
  • perfect square
  • rational numbers
  • none

Support for Building Character 

Throughout this unit, find ways to encourage and support students to work on cultivating their intellectual humility.

Here are some tips to try during this lesson:

  • More Than Meets the Eye
  • Admitting Mistakes

You can find other tips located here in the Playbook on Intellectual Humility from Character Lab.

page.title: 9.3.1: Solving Equations with Fractions
page.contents:
Warm Up (5 minutes)

The purpose of this Math Talk is to elicit strategies and understandings students have for operations on fractions and solving equations. These understandings help students develop fluency and will be helpful later in this lesson when students will need to use similar computations to solve quadratic equations.

Launch

Display one problem at a time. Give students quiet think time for each problem and ask them to give a signal when they have an answer and a strategy. Keep all problems displayed throughout the talk. Follow with a whole-class discussion.

Student Activity

Solve each equation mentally.

  1. \(x+x=\frac14\)

Write down your answer, then select the solution button to compare your work.

Answer: \(x=\frac18\)

  1. \((\frac{3}{2})^2=x\)

Write down your answer, then select the solution button to compare your work.

Answer: \(x=\frac94\)

  1. \(\frac{3}{5}+x=\frac95\)

Write down your answer, then select the solution button to compare your work.

Answer: \(x=\frac65\)

  1. \(\frac{1}{12}+x=\frac14\)

Write down your answer in simplest form, then select the solution button to compare your work.

Answer: \(x=\frac16\)

Activity Synthesis

Ask students to share their strategies for each problem. Record and display their responses for all to see. To involve more students in the conversation, consider asking:

  • "Who can restate __________'s reasoning in a different way?"
  • "Did anyone have the same strategy but would explain it differently?"
  • "Did anyone solve the problem in a different way?"
  • "Does anyone want to add on to __________'s strategy?"
  • "Do you agree or disagree? Why?"

page.title: 9.3.2: Using Completing the Square to Solve Equations
page.contents:
Activity (20 minutes)

In this activity, students encounter equations that contain rational numbers. They learn that, even though the numbers are not as straightforward as in equations they have previously seen, they can still solve the equations by completing the square. The less-friendly numbers and the more elaborate equations make the computations more challenging, so students need to attend to precision and mind the steps for rearranging parts of the equations, as well as the signs of the numbers, especially negative numbers.

As students work, they may need to be reminded to rewrite the equation in a different form, isolate a term to make it easier to complete the square, apply the zero product property only when a product is equal to zero, and so on. Make note of common errors or hurdles and address them during whole-class discussion.

Launch

Give students a moment to look at the list of equations and notice how they are like or unlike other equations they have seen and solved before. Invite students to share some observations. They may notice, for instance:

  • \((x−3)(x+1)=5\) does not have 0 on one side, so we cannot use the zero product property right away.
  • \(x^2+\frac{1}{2}x=\frac{3}{16}\) and \(x^2+3x+\frac{8}{4}=0\) involve fractions.
  • \(x^2+3x+\frac{8}{4}=0\) has an odd number for the coefficient of the linear term.
  • \((7−x)(3−x)+3=0\) has 0 on one side but the other side is a sum, not a product.
  • \(x^2+1.6x+0.63=0\) has decimals.

Explain to students that each equation can be solved by completing the square and using the same reasoning as when we solved simpler-looking equations earlier.

Consider arranging students in groups of two. If there is not enough time for students to answer all the questions, consider asking students to look at the list of equations and to choose one they think looks easier (or more familiar) and one that looks harder (or less familiar).

Student Activity

Completing the square can be used to solve quadratic equations.

Example: Solve \(x^2+8x-2=0\).

To complete the square to solve an equation, follow these steps:

Step 1
Write the equation in the form \(ax^2+bx=c\).
\(x^2+8x=-2\)

Step 2
Complete the square by finding \((\frac{b}{2})^2\).
\((\frac{b}{2})^2=(\frac{8}{2})^2=16\)

Step 3
Add the value to both sides of the equation.
\(x^2+8x+16=-2+16\)

Step 4
Factor the perfect square trinomial and simplify the constants.
\((x+4)^2=14\)

Step 5
Take the square root of each side (remember the plus-minus sign with the constant).
\(\sqrt{(x+4)^2}=\sqrt{14}\)
\(x+4= \pm \sqrt{14}\)

Step 6
Write two separate equations and solve each.
\(x + 4 = \sqrt{14}\)  or  \(x + 4 =\; - \;\sqrt{14}\)
\(x = -4 + \sqrt{14}\)  or  \(x =\; -\;4\; -\; \sqrt{14}\)

Solve each equation by completing the square. In part a, select the value of \((\frac{b}{2})^2\) that will complete the square. In part b, choose the two roots.

  1. \((x−3)(x+1)=5\)
  1. What is the correct value of \((\frac{b}{2})^2\) that will complete the square?

Answer: 1

  1. Select two roots that solve the quadratic equation.
  • \(x = -2\)
  • \(x = 1\)
  • \(x = 8\)
  • \(x = 4\)
  • \(x = 9\)

Answer: \(x = -2\), \(x = 4\)

  1. \(x^2+\frac{1}{2}x=\frac{3}{16}\)
  1. What is the correct value of \((\frac{b}{2})^2\) that will complete the square?

Answer: \((\frac{b}{2})^2= \frac{1}{16}\)

  1. Select two roots that solve the quadratic equation.
  • \(x = \frac12\)
  • \(x = \frac14\)
  • \(x = -\frac34\)
  • \(x = -\frac14\)
  • \(x = 1\)

Answer: \(x=\frac14\), \(x=-\frac34\)

  1. \(x^2+3x+\frac{8}{4}=0\)
  1. What is the correct value of \((\frac{b}{2})^2\) that will complete the square?

Answer: \((\frac{b}{2})^2= \frac94\)

  1. Select two roots that solve the quadratic equation.
  • \(x = -2\)
  • \(x=\frac{1}{16}\)
  • \(x = 9\)
  • \(x = \frac14\)
  • \(x = -1\)

Answer: \(x = -2\), \(x = -1\)

  1. \((7−x)(3−x)+3=0\)
  1. What is the correct value of \((\frac{b}{2})^2\) that will complete the square?

Answer: 25

  1. Select two roots that solve the quadratic equation.
  • \(x = -2\)
  • \(x = 6\)
  • \(x = 21\)
  • \(x = 4\)
  • \(x = 9\)

Answer: \(x = 6\), \(x = 4\)

  1. \(x^2+1.6x+0.63=0\)
  1. What is the correct value of \((\frac{b}{2})^2\) that will complete the square?

Answer: 0.64

  1. Select two roots that solve the quadratic equation.
  • \(x = -0.7\)
  • \(x = 0.4\)
  • \(x = 0.27\)
  • \(x = 0.7\)
  • \(x = -0.9\)

Answer: \(x = -0.7\), \(x = -0.9\)

Video: Solve by Completing the Square

Watch the following video to learn more about solving to complete the square.



Anticipated Misconceptions

Some students may have a difficult time getting started given the increased complexity of these problems. Encourage these students to use completing the square to solve a more familiar problem first, such as \(x^2−10x+20=4\), and then to use the structure of the process they followed as a guide to help them solve these more challenging problems.

Activity Synthesis

Select students to share their solutions and display their work for all to see. If students found solutions that differ from each other, as time permits, invite these students to describe their thinking to the class, and encourage them to try to identify any errors and determine which solutions are correct. Discuss any common challenges or errors.

Make sure students understand that the process of solving by completing the square is the same whether the numbers in the equations are integers or other rational numbers. Elicit from students a generalization of the process. For example:

  • Start with a quadratic expression in standard form on one side of the equal sign and a number (which could be 0) on the other side.
  • Take half of the coefficient of the linear term and square it. The result is the constant term that would make the quadratic expression a perfect square.
  • Perform the same operations to both sides of the equal sign so that the constant term that is on one side is a perfect square that makes the expression a perfect square.
  • Rewrite the expression (in standard form) as a squared factor.
  • Find both values of the factor that, when squared, give the number on the other side of the equal sign.

To scaffold instruction, provide a blank template with the steps for students to follow as they solve equations.

9.3.2: Self Check 

After the activity, students will answer the following question to check their understanding of the concepts explored in the activity.

QUESTION:

After solving using completing the square, what are the zeros of the quadratic equation \(x^2+5x+ \frac{9}{4}=0\) ?

ANSWERS

FEEDBACK

\(x=\frac{1}{4}\) , \(x=-\frac{19}{4}\)

Incorrect. Let's try again a different way: After adding the \((\frac{b}{2})^2\), make sure to take the square root of both sides. The answer is \(x=\frac{-1}{2}\), \(x=\frac{-9}{2}\).

\(x=\frac{25}{4}\)

Incorrect. Let's try again a different way: This is the value of \((\frac{b}{2})^2\), not a zero. The answer is \(x=\frac{-1}{2}\), \(x=\frac{-9}{2}\).

\(x= \frac{-1}{2}\), \(x=\frac{-9}{2}\)

That's correct! Check yourself: Move the \(\frac94\) to the other side of the equation then complete the square and add \(\frac{25}{4}\) to each side. Take the square root of each side then factor. The equation becomes \(x+ \frac{5}{2}= \pm \;2\). Solve for \(x\) and these are the zeros.

\(x= \frac12\)

Incorrect. Let's try again a different way: The perfect square binomial created is \((x+\frac{5}{2})^2\) but this does not give the zero. The answer is \(x=\frac{-1}{2}\), \(x=\frac{-9}{2}\).

9.3.2: Additional Resources

The following content is available to students who would like more support based on their experience with the self check. Students will not automatically have access to this content, so you may wish to share it with those who could benefit from it. 

Completing the Square with Fractions

Completing the square can be a useful method for solving quadratic equations in cases in which it is not easy to rewrite an expression in factored form. For example, let's solve this equation:

\(x^2 + 5x - \frac{75}{4}=0\)

First, we'll add \(\frac{75}{4}\) to each side to make things easier on ourselves.

\(x^2+5x-\frac{75}{4}+\frac{75}{4}=0+\frac{75}{4}\)

\(x^2+5x=\frac{75}{4}\)

To complete the square, take \(\frac12\) of the coefficient of the linear term 5, which is \(\frac52\), and square it, which is \(\frac{25}{5}\). Add this to each side:

\(x^2 +5x +\frac{25}{4}=\frac{75}{4}+\frac{25}{4}\)

 \(x^2+5x +\frac{25}{4}=\frac{100}{4}\)

Notice that \(\frac{100}{4}\) is equal to 25 and rewrite it:

\(x^2+5x+\frac{25}{4}=25\)

Since the left side is now a perfect square, let's rewrite it:

\((x+\frac{5}{2})^2=25\)

For this equation to be true, one of these equations must be true:

\(x+\frac{5}{2}=5\) or \(x+\frac{5}{2}=-5\)

To finish up, we can subtract \(\frac52\) from each side of the equal sign in each equation.

\(x=5-\frac52\) or \(x=-5-\frac52\)

\(x=\frac52\) or \(x=-\frac{15}{2}\)

\(x=2\frac12\) or \(x=-7\frac12\)

It takes some practice to become proficient at completing the square, but it makes it possible to solve many more equations than you could by methods you learned previously.

Try It: Completing the Square with Fractions

Solve \(x^2+3x-4=0\) using completing the square, then find the zeros of the quadratic equation.

Write down your answer, then select the solution button to compare your work.

Solution

Here is how to find the zeros after using completing the square:

Step 1
Add the constant to the other side of the equation.
\(x^2+3x=4\)

Step 2
Complete the square.
\((\frac{3}{2})^2=\frac94\)

Step 3
Add the constant to each side.
\(x^2+3x+\frac{9}{4}=\frac{16}{4}+\frac94\)

Step 4
Simplify and factor the perfect square trinomial.
\((x+\frac{3}{2})^2=\frac{25}{4}\)

Step 5
Take the square root of both sides of the equation.
\(x+\frac{3}{2}= \pm \frac{5}{2}\)

Step 6
Write the two equations and solve. 
\(x+\frac{3}{2}=\frac{5}{2}\) and \(x+\frac{3}{2}=-\frac{5}{2}\)
\(x=1\)                             \(x=-4\)

page.title: 9.3.3: Solve by Completing the Square
page.contents:
Activity (10 minutes)

In this activity, students analyze worked examples of equations solved by completing the square. The work allows them to further develop their understanding of the method when used with rational numbers and to notice common errors. Identifying errors in worked examples is an opportunity to attend to precision and to analyze and critique the reasoning of others.

Launch

Display the four equations in the task statement for all to see:

  • \(x^2+14x=-24\)
  • \(x^2−10x+16=0\)
  • \(x^2+2.4x=-0.8\)
  • \(x^2−\frac{6}{5}x+\frac{1}{5}=0\)

Arrange students in groups of three to four. Assign one equation (or more, depending on time constraints) for each group to solve by completing the square. Once group members agree on the solutions, ask them to look for errors in the worked solution for the same equation (as the one they solved).

Student Activity

Here are four equations followed by worked solutions of the equations. Each solution has at least one error.

  1. Solve the equation \(x^2+14x=-24\). Then look at the following worked solution (with errors) and find and describe the error or errors in the worked solution.

\(\begin{array}{rlr}x^{2}+14 x & =-24 & \text { Step 1 } \\ x^{2}+14 x+28 & =4 & \text { Step 2 } \\ (x+7)^{2} & =4 & \text { Step 3 } \\ x + 7 & =2 & \text { Step 4 } \\ x+7 & =-2 & \text { Step 5 } \\ x & =-5 \text { and } x=9 & \text { Step 6 } \\ \end{array} \)

Write down your answer, then select the solution button to compare your work.

Answer: \(x=-2\) and \(x=-12\)

Error: In Step 2, the number being added, 28, is not a perfect square. It should be 49.

  1. Solve the equation \(x^2−10x+16=0\). Then look at the following worked solution (with errors) and find and describe the error or errors in the worked solution.

\(\begin{array}{rlr} x^{2}-10 x+16 & =0 & \text { Step 1 } \\ x^{2}-10 x+25 & =9 & \text { Step 2 } \\ (x-5)^{2} & =9 & \text { Step 3 } \\ x-5 & =9 & \text { Step 4 } \\ x-5 & =-9 & \text { Step 5 } \\ x=14 & \text { and } x=-4 & \text { Step 6 } \end{array} \)

Write down your answer, then select the solution button to compare your work.

Answer: \(x=8\) and \(x=2\)

Errors: Step 4 should have 3 on the right side, not 9. Step 5 should have -3 on the right side, not -9.

  1. Solve the equation \(x^2+2.4x=-0.8\). Then look at the following worked solution (with errors) and find and describe the error or errors in the worked solution.

\(\begin{array}{rlr}x^2+2.4x=-0.8\;\;\text{ Step 1}& \\ x^2+2.4x+1.44=0.64\quad\text{Step 2}& \\ (x+1.2)^2=0.64\quad\text{Step 3}& \\ x+1.2=0.8\quad\text{Step 4}& \\ x=-0.4\quad\text{Step 5}&\end{array} \)

Write down your answer, then select the solution button to compare your work.

Answer: \(x=-0.4\) and \(x=-2\)

Error: In Step 4, only the positive square root is written and the negative square root is neglected.

  1. Solve the equation \(x^2−\frac{6}{5}x+\frac{1}{5}=0\). Then look at the following worked solution (with errors) and find and describe the error or errors in the worked solution.

\(\begin{array}{rlr}x^2-\frac65x+\frac15&=0&\text{Step 1}\\x^2-\frac65x+\frac9{25}&=\frac9{25}&\text{Step 2}\\\left(x-\frac35\right)^2&=\frac9{25}&\text{Step 3}\\x-\frac35&=\frac35&\text{Step 4}\\x-\frac35&=-\frac35&\text{Step 5}\\x=\frac65&\text{ and }x=0&\text{Step 6}\end{array}\)

Write down your answer, then select the solution button to compare your work.

Answer: \(x=1\) and \(x=\frac{1}{5}\)

Errors: For example:
In Step 2, different amounts are added to each side. On the left, \(\frac{4}{25}\) is added. On the right, \(\frac{9}{25}\) is added. Or: While \(\frac{9}{25}\) is added on the right side, \(\frac{1}{5}\) was only subtracted from the left side. Other explanations may also be accurate.

Activity Synthesis

To involve more students in the discussion, after each student presents, consider asking students to classify each error by type (not limited to one type per error) and explain their classification. Here are some examples of types of errors:

  • Careless errors—for example, writing the wrong number or symbol, repeating the same step twice, leaving out a negative sign, or not following directions.
  • Computational errors—for example, adding or subtracting incorrectly or putting a decimal point in the wrong place.
  • Gaps in understanding—for example, misunderstanding of the problem or the rules of algebra, applying an ineffective strategy, or choosing the wrong operation or step.
  • Lack of precision or incomplete communication—for example, missing steps or explanations, incorrect notation, or forgetting labels or parentheses.

9.3.3: Self Check 

After the activity, students will answer the following question to check their understanding of the concepts explored in the activity.

QUESTION:

Examine the work shown. Which of the following is the error that took place when the equation was solved by completing the square?

\(x^2-6x-7=0\)

\(x^2-6x=7\)

\(x^2-6x+9=16\)

\((x-3)^2=16\)

\(x-3=4\)

\(x=7\)

ANSWERS

FEEDBACK

The 7 should have been subtracted from each side.

Incorrect. Let's try again a different way: The inverse operation was correctly used and 7 was added to both sides. The correct answer is: When taking the square root, only the positive solution was included.

When taking the square root, only the positive solution was included.

That's correct! Check yourself: When taking \(\sqrt{(x-3)^2}=\sqrt{16}\) the positive and negative 4s must be considered so that \(x-3= \pm \; 4\).

When completing the square, the wrong number was found for \((\frac{b}{2})^2\).

Incorrect. Let's try again a different way: \((\frac{6}{2})^2=9\) so the square was completed correctly. The correct answer is when taking the square root, only the positive solution was included.

This equation cannot be solved by completing the square.

Incorrect. Let's try again a different way: This problem can be solved by completing the square since it is a quadratic equation with a real coefficient of \(x\). The correct answer is: When taking the square root, only the positive solution was included.

9.3.3: Additional Resources

The following content is available to students who would like more support based on their experience with the self check. Students will not automatically have access to this content, so you may wish to share it with those who could benefit from it. 

Spotting the Error When Solving Quadratics

To find the error when solving quadratics, it is helpful to first solve the problem on your own.

Solve the quadratic equation by completing the square and finding its zeros. Identify the error in the worked solution below.

\(\begin{array}{ll} x^{2}+10 x-34=0 & \text { Step 1 } \\ x^{2}+10 x=34 & \text { Step 2 } \\ x^{2}+10 x+25=34-25 & \text { Step 3 } \\ (x+5)^{2}=9 & \text { Step 4 } \\ x+5=\pm \; 3 & \text { Step 5 } \\ x=-8, x=-2 & \text { Step 6 } \end{array} \)

Now, find the error by working through the problem and comparing steps:

\(\begin{array}{ll} x^{2}+10 x-34=0 & \text { Step 1 } \\ x^{2}+10 x=34 & \text { Step 2 } \\ x^{2}+10 x+25=34+25 & \text { Step 3 } \end{array} \)

In Step 3, 25 was added to the left side of the equation, but 25 was SUBTRACTED from the right side of the equation. Equations must remain balanced, and 25 should be added to each side of the equation.

Try It: Spotting the Error When Solving Quadratics

Examine the steps below and identify the error in solving the quadratic equation by completing the square:

\(\begin{array}{lcc}x^2+8x+7=0&\text{ Step 1 }& \\ x^2+8x=-7&\text{ Step 2 }& \\ x^2+8x+16=-7+16&\text{ Step 3 }& \\ (x+4)^2=9&\text{ Step 4 }& \\ x+4=3&\text{ Step 5 }& \\ x=-1&\text{ Step 6 }&\end{array} \)

Write down your answer, then select the solution button to compare your work.

Solution

Here is how to find the error when completing the square:

Work through the steps on your own and compare:

\(\begin{array}{lc}x^2+8x+7=0&\text{ Step 1 } \\ x^2+8x=-7&\text{ Step 2 } \\ x^2+8x+16=-7+16&\text{ Step 3 } \\ (x+4)^2=9&\text{ Step 4 } \\ x+4=\pm3&\text{ Step 5 } \\ x=-1,x=-7&\text{ Step 6 }\end{array}\)

The error occurred in Step 5 when the plus-minus sign was not included after taking the square root of each side. This led to the second possible equation not being written.

page.title: 9.3.4: Completing the Square with Fractions
page.contents:
Cool Down (5 minutes)

Activity

The solutions to this equation are \(x = \frac{3}{4}\) and \(x=\frac{1}{4}\). Show how to find those solutions by completing the square. \(x^2−x+\frac{3}{16}=0\)

Write down your answer, then select the solution button to compare your work.

Answer:

\(\begin{array}{rcl}x^2-x+\frac3{16}&=&0\\x^2-x+\frac14&=&-\frac3{16}+\frac14=-\frac3{16}+\frac4{16}=\frac1{16}\\x^2-x+\frac14&=&\frac1{16}\\\sqrt{\left(x-\frac12\right)^2}&=&\sqrt{\frac1{16}}\\x-\frac12&=&\pm\frac14\\x-\frac12&=&\frac14\\x-\frac12&=&-\frac14\end{array}\)
\( \;\;\;\;\;\;\;\;\;\;x=\frac{1}{4} \text { and } x=\frac{3}{4}\)

Response to Student Thinking

More Chances

Students will have more opportunities to understand the mathematical ideas in this cool down, so there is no need to slow down or add additional work to the next lessons. Instead, use the results of this cool down to provide guidance for what to look for and emphasize over the next several lessons to support students in advancing their current understanding.

page.title: 9.3.5: Practice
page.contents:
Students will complete the following questions to practice the skills they have learned in this lesson.

For the expressions in questions 1–4, choose which number would make the expression a perfect square. Then, choose an equivalent expression in factored form.

  1. \(x^2+3x\)
  1. What number can be added to make \(x^2+3x\) a perfect square?
  • \(\frac23\)
  • \(\frac49\)
  • \(\frac94\)
  • \(-\frac23\)

Answer: \(\frac94\)

  1. Which expression is equivalent to \(x^2+3x\)?
  • \(x(x + 3)\)
  • \(x(3x)\)
  • \((x + 3)(x + 3)\)
  • \(3(x + 1)\)

Answer: \(x(x + 3)\)

  1. \(x^2+0.6x\)
  1. What number can be added to make \(x^2+0.6x\) a perfect square?
  • 0.09
  • 0.81
  • 0.36
  • 0.03

Answer: 0.09

  1. Which expression is equivalent to \(x^2+0.6x\)?
  • \( x(x+0.6x)\)
  • \(x(x+0.06)\)
  • \(x(0.6x)\)
  • \(0.6(x+1)\)

Answer: \(x(x+0.06)\)

  1. \(x^2-11x\)
  1. What number can be added to make \(x^2-11x\) a perfect square?
  • \(\frac{11}{2}\)
  • \(\frac{25}{2}\)
  • \(\frac52\)
  • \(\frac{121}{4}\)

Answer: \(\frac{121}{4}\)

  1. Which expression is equivalent to \(x^2-11x\)?
  • \(x(x-11x)\)
  • \(x(x-11)\)
  • \(11(x-1)\)
  • \(11x(x-1)\)

Answer: \(x(x-11)\)

  1. \(x^2-\frac{5}{2}x\)
  1. What number can be added to make \(x^2-\frac{5}{2}x\) a perfect square?
  • \(\frac{25}{4}\)
  • \(\frac{25}{16}\)
  • \(\frac58\)
  • \(\frac68\)

Answer: \(\frac{25}{16}\)

  1. Which expression is equivalent to \(x^2-\frac{5}{2}x\)?
  • \(x(x-\frac52)\)
  • \(x(x-\frac{5}{2}x)\)
  • \(\frac{5}{2}x(x-1)\)
  • \(\frac{5}{2}(x-1)\)

Answer: \(x(x-\frac52)\)

  1. What number can be added to make \(x^2+x\) a perfect square?
  • \(\frac14\)
  • \(\frac12\)
  • 1
  • 0

Answer: \(\frac14\)

  1. What number can be added to make \(x^2-\frac{3}{2}x\) a perfect square?  
  • \(\frac23\)
  • \(\frac49\)
  • \(\frac{9}{16}\)
  • \(-\frac23\)

Answer: \(\frac{9}{16}\)

  1. Noah is solving the equation \(x^2+8x+15=3\). He begins by rewriting the expression on the left in factored form and writes \((x+3)(x+5)=3\). He does not know what to do next. 
  1. Do you think using the factored form is the best way for Noah to solve this equation?
  • Yes
  • No

Answer: No

  1. Solve the original equation, then choose the two roots.
  • \(x = -4\)
  • \(x = 12\)
  • \(x = -2\)
  • \(x = -6\)
  • \(x = 4\)

Answer: \(x = -2\), \(x = -6\)

  1. An equation and its solutions are given. Solve the equation by completing the square, then choose whether you agree or disagree with the given solutions.
  1. \(x^2+20x+50=14\). The solutions are \(x=-18\) and \(x=2\).
  • Agree
  • Disagree

Answer: Disagree. The correct solutions are \(x=-18\) and \(x=2\).

  1. \(x^2+1.6x=0.36\). The solutions are \(x=-1.8\) and \(x=0.2\).
  • Agree
  • Disagree

Answer: Agree. \(x=-1.8\) and \(x=0.2\)

  1. \(x^2-5x=\frac{11}{4}\). The solutions are \(x=\frac{11}{4}\) and \(x=-12\).
  • Agree
  • Disagree

Answer: Disagree. The correct solutions are \(x=\frac{11}{2}\) and \(x=-\frac12\).

  1. Solve each equation, then choose the two roots.
  1. \(x^2-0.5x=0.5\)
  • \(x = -0.5\)
  • \(x = 1\)
  • \( x = 0\)
  • \(x = 2\)
  • \(x = -1\)

Answer: \(x = -0.5\), \(x = 1\)

  1. \(x^2+0.8x=0.09\)
  • \(x = -0.9\)
  • \(x = 0.8\)
  • \(x = 0.4\)
  • \(x = 0.1\)
  • \(x = 0.81\)

Answer: \(x = -0.9\), \(x = 0.1\)

  1. \(x^2+\frac{13}{3}x=\frac{56}{36}\)
  • \(x = \frac{28}{3}\)
  • \(x =\frac{1}{9}\)
  • \(x=\frac{112}{36}\)
  • \(x=-\frac{14}{3}\)
  • \(x = \frac13\)

Answer: \(x=-\frac{14}{3}\), \(x=\frac13\)

page.title: 9.3.6: Lesson Synthesis
page.contents:
To help students generalize the process of solving quadratic equations by completing the square, ask students,

  • "How was the process of completing the square in this lesson different than that in an earlier lesson?" (The numbers in the equations are not as simple, so the calculations may be more involved and time consuming. In some cases, more steps were needed to complete the square, and the process may be more prone to error.)
  • "How was the process of completing the square in this lesson like that in the previous lesson?" (The steps are essentially the same: turn one side into a perfect-square expression, write it as a squared factor, and reason about the value of the factor.)
  • "What are some errors you have seen or have made when the solving process involves multiple steps, especially when the numbers are tricky to work with?" (Some common errors:
    • Only positive solutions are shown. Negative solutions are neglected.
    • Different amounts are added to the two sides of the equal sign.
    • The wrong amount is added so the quadratic expression is not a perfect square.
    • Incorrect calculations or missed steps.)
  • "When might we want to choose to solve quadratic equations by rewriting them in factored form instead of by completing the square? When might it be preferable to complete the square?" (When we could easily see the factors in a quadratic equation, then it makes sense to solve the equation by putting it in factored form. When it is not obvious what the factors are, or when the equation involves non-integers, then completing the square may be preferable.)

Emphasize that completing the square is a handy technique that can be used to solve any quadratic equation, but depending on the numbers in the equation, it may or may not be an efficient method.
